description: From Middle English hauberk, from Old French hauberc, from Frankish *halsaberg (“neck-cover”).

entries.meaning: A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of the European Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which is shorter and sometimes sleeveless.
(less common) A similar shirt of scale mail, plate, leather, or other armor material.
examples: The habergeon is the mail in this case, and the hauberk is of plate or splint armour, while the cote-armoure is the surcoat, possibly thickly padded, as in the still-existing surcoat of the Black Prince.
